posts.name: Nolan Locke
posts.cooked: I’ve seen the calculators that give you estimated feedforward gain for arms and elevators, but is there a reason something like this doesn’t exist for drivetrains? It seems like something where you could input the module brand, gear ratio, motor type and robot weight and the value would be the same regardless of what the rest of the robot looks like. Is there something that is significantly more complicated than what it sounds like to calculate that? Or could some kind of table be built by teams testing a setup with different weights? I guess the root question would be if there are two robots with identical swerve setups and the same weight, would the pid + feedforward constants be the same?

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
ReCalc will give you kV and kA for a drivetrain.

For kS, you need data on the actual mechanism, but you could probably characterize a few different modules if you wanted to.

posts.name: Andrew Samulyak
posts.cooked: You can run a system identification routine to find an accurate feedforward gain, we did it on our drivetrain and it worked very well. Check out Creating an Identification Routine — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation and allwpilib/wpilibjExamples/src/main/java/edu/wpi/first/wpilibj/examples/sysid at main · wpilibsuite/allwpilib · GitHub to help you set it up in code. Basically it runs a test on your wheels spinning them under different speeds and it derives the different feedforward values to use on your controller. this test is significantly more complicated than just putting info into a calculator but it’s worth doing if you want a more accurate controller on your drivetrain

link_counts.title: Creating an Identification Routine — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: it’s pretty trivial to tweak by hand - just figure out the largest voltage you can send to the motors without them moving.

posts.name: Nolan Locke
posts.cooked: Yeah this is what we currently do, but I was wondering why it would differ between robots assuming they all have the same mechanism. I guess each module would have slightly different static friction, but I don’t think that would affect things? Maybe it would, I’m not too familiar with the inner workings of this stuff.
